general_texts:
Thank you for your interest in Cal Poly San Luis Obispo!

This articulation agreement displays the lower-division courses required in major and support. Students are advised to complete as much lower-division course preparation as possible prior to transfer. Cal Poly has specific selection criteria for transfer students for admissions, and we encourage you to check the selection criteria for the major you are interested in. 

GENERAL INFORMATION

  • University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements for this major
  • Admissions website for current transfer admission requirements
  • Cal Poly website for information on our campus


ACADEMIC INFORMATION

  • Curriculum sheets & flowcharts for Cal Poly majors | this will show you information about concentrations if applicable in your major
  • AP/IB exams and test credits earned & policies on college-level examination program exams  
  • Academic Advising  
  • How to use Assist.org 


The Other Courses section is omitted for this major as neither concentration, (Aeronautics and Astronautics), has lower division courses, nor does it have any areas of emphasis or free electives. Please refer to curriculum sheets and flowcharts link above.

Cal Poly is currently on the quarter system, and all Cal Poly course units reflect that format. Starting Fall 2026, the university will switch to the semester system. If you begin at Cal Poly in Fall 2025, Cal Poly will make every effort to ensure a seamless transfer of your community college work, so that you make progress-to-degree. ASSIST agreements, flowcharts, curriculum sheets, and planning tools haven’t been updated yet to show semester-based information. For latest updates, visit Cal Poly’s official semester conversion page: 


  • Semester conversion website 
  • Specific College semester conversion websites

To be a competitive transfer applicant, it’s important to start by reviewing Cal Poly’s Selection Criteria for Transfer Students for your major of interest. This page outlines general admissions requirements for all transfer applicants and the required and desired courses for admissions to Cal Poly San Luis Obispo.  


Once you know which courses are expected, use ASSIST to see how your completed or planned courses match Cal Poly’s. You can search articulation agreements by major, department, or course prefix. Keep in mind that credit is granted based on the academic year in which you took the course. 


Note: Not all articulated courses listed in ASSIST are required to be a competitive applicant—but completing the required courses in the selection criteria and as many recommended courses as possible will strengthen your application. 

  

This is not a static document; new articulation may be added at any time. The information provided herein is subject to change without notice and does not constitute a contract or the terms and conditions of a contract between the student and the institution or the California State University.

Thank you for your interest in Cal Poly San Luis Obispo!

This articulation agreement displays the lower-division courses required in major and support. Students are advised to complete as much lower-division course preparation as possible prior to transfer. Cal Poly has specific selection criteria for transfer students for admissions, and we encourage you to check the selection criteria for the major you are interested in. 

GENERAL INFORMATION

  • University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements for this major
  • Admissions website for current transfer admission requirements
  • Cal Poly website for information on our campus


ACADEMIC INFORMATION

  • Curriculum sheets & flowcharts for Cal Poly majors | this will show you information about concentrations if applicable in your major
  • AP/IB exams and test credits earned & policies on college-level examination program exams  
  • Academic Advising  
  • How to use Assist.org 


This major has three concentrations; Health Promotion, Exercise Science, and Sport Science. Lower division courses (including approved elective options) which may be in one or more of these concentrations are listed. This major has no areas of emphasis. Although not listed here, this major has 9 units of free electives. Please refer to curriculum sheets and flowcharts link above.

To be a competitive transfer applicant, it’s important to start by reviewing Cal Poly’s Selection Criteria for Transfer Students for your major of interest. This page outlines general admissions requirements for all transfer applicants and the required and desired courses for admissions to Cal Poly San Luis Obispo.  Once you know which courses are expected, use ASSIST to see how your completed or planned courses match Cal Poly’s. You can search articulation agreements by major, department, or course prefix. Keep in mind that credit is granted based on the academic year in which you took the course. 


Note: Not all articulated courses listed in ASSIST are required to be a competitive applicant—but completing the required courses in the selection criteria and as many recommended courses as possible will strengthen your application. 

  

This is not a static document; new articulation may be added at any time. The information provided herein is subject to change without notice and does not constitute a contract or the terms and conditions of a contract between the student and the institution or the California State University.

Cal Poly is currently on the quarter system, and all Cal Poly course units reflect that format. Starting Fall 2026, the university will switch to the semester system. If you begin at Cal Poly in Fall 2025, Cal Poly will make every effort to ensure a seamless transfer of your community college work, so that you make progress-to-degree. ASSIST agreements, flowcharts, curriculum sheets, and planning tools haven’t been updated yet to show semester-based information. For latest updates, visit Cal Poly’s official semester conversion page: 


  • Semester conversion website 
  • Specific College semester conversion websites

general_titles: NOTE CONCERNING "MAJOR COURSES" SECTION FOR THIS MAJOR REGARDING ME 128 & ME 129
general_texts:
For this major, transfer students should take ME 129 & 130 instead of ME 228. Any articulation with ME 129 & 130 should be mirrored with ME 228, only listed in the “By Department” or “By Prefix” views. Subsequently, after transferring into the program, transfer students should plan on taking ME 263 + 264 during their first quarter on campus, (rather than ME 128 and ME 163 or any articulated equivalents), as these courses are specifically designed for Mechanical Engineering transfer students. Course outlines can be found here: https://catalog.calpoly.edu/coursesaz/me/


 This major has five concentrations; General, Energy Resources, Manufacturing, Mechatronics, and Heating, Ventilating, Air-Conditioning and Refrigerating. Lower division courses (including electives, technical electives and emphasis areas) which may be in one or more of these concentrations are listed. Please refer to curriculum sheets and flowcharts link above.

This page outlines general admissions requirements for all transfer applicants and the required and desired courses for admissions to Cal Poly San Luis Obispo.  Once you know which courses are expected, use ASSIST to see how your completed or planned courses match Cal Poly’s. You can search articulation agreements by major, department, or course prefix. Keep in mind that credit is granted based on the academic year in which you took the course. 


Note: Not all articulated courses listed in ASSIST are required to be a competitive applicant—but completing the required courses in the selection criteria and as many recommended courses as possible will strengthen your application. 

  

This is not a static document; new articulation may be added at any time. The information provided herein is subject to change without notice and does not constitute a contract or the terms and conditions of a contract between the student and the institution or the California State University.

Cal Poly is currently on the quarter system, and all Cal Poly course units reflect that format. Starting Fall 2026, the university will switch to the semester system. If you begin at Cal Poly in Fall 2025, Cal Poly will make every effort to ensure a seamless transfer of your community college work, so that you make progress-to-degree. ASSIST agreements, flowcharts, curriculum sheets, and planning tools haven’t been updated yet to show semester-based information. For latest updates, visit Cal Poly’s official semester conversion page:
